A blackbox in the car ?

American road planners are looking for a money source to repair the declining Highway system , and believe the solution has been found in a small black box that can be found in the dashboard of every car .

The devices that record every kilometre driven and report information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the planning agencies of the states to revise the obsolete system of financing US roads .
The normally boring area of road planning has suddenly launched an intensive debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied to environmental groups and are in favour of the government being able to use small boxes to record the kilometres that have been dropped – and possibly where they have been driven – and then to use the information to calculate tax models .
The Tea Party is apparent .
The American Citizens ' Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states no longer wait .
They are currently examining how they can switch over the next decade to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
That really is a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing we can only use , ” says Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assen of Governments , which plans a record of the fed miles on all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 .
The way in which we pay these taxes will change . to to .
There is technology for that .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , which is financed from the taxes that US Americans pay in the tap column , has failed .
But in America no longer as much gets done as before .
Cars use fewer petrol .
The national mineral oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 Eurocent per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax even for a single cent at high peak prices .
“ The petrol tax is simply not feasible for the future , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert on transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
Recently , his state has equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a milestone payment system .
“ This is the most meaningful alternative in the long term , ” he said .
It is a milestone user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is found with urban Liberal liberals , for example , because the tax could be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way that congestion and climate-damaging exhaust gases are reduced .

The freelancers of the Reason Foundation are also invited to pay drivers back .
“ This is no tax that disappears in a black hole , ” says Adrian Moore , Vice-President of Reason Directives .

The movement is also supported by two former American transport ministers , who in a 2011 report called on Congress to move toward milestone settlements .
Last year , the US Senate approved a 90 million dollars of expensive pilot project , which would cover 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of members from rural areas who represent people who , in everyday life , often have to put many miles on the road to work or to the city .
Several states and major cities are nevertheless moving in this direction .
The most committed is Oregon , which currently purchases 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage charges instead of the oil tax on the federal state .

The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the equipment , drivers were skeptical about thinking that the government could follow any of their movements .

The hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company originally did not start to help states tax drivers .
Instead , it was their aim to foot in an emerging market for vehicle insurance , where drivers are supposed to pay on the basis of the miles that have gone .
But their tested devices are also interesting to road planners , because they do not work with GPS and deliver limited information that is regularly uploaded by modem .
